You remove the stopper from the Draught of Healing and pour the liquid inside into your mouth. It has a fruity taste and makes your tongue tingle, and when you swallow it you feel warmth coursing through your whole body.
I feel renewed!

You remove the stopper from the Vial of Immortality and pour the liquid inside into your mouth. It has a sweet taste and sends a chill through your teeth for a moment, and when you swallow it your body glows for a moment.
My reign shall be eternal!

You gaze out across [Root.Location.GetName], holding the Living Flame in one hand in front of you. It senses what you might ask of it.\n\n"UNLEASH ME, AND I SHALL BURN THIS LAND TO ASHES!" it says. "ALL SHALL BURN! ALL SHALL BE CONSUMED BY THE FLAME! ALL SHALL FEAR YOU!"
Burn them all!
I think that is a bit excessive...

[From.Location.GetName] burns, set ablaze by the power wielded by [From.GetBestName]. Many fail to escape the flames as they consume the province. It is doubtful that the province will recover anytime soon, and it equally doubtful that [From.GetBestName] can be trusted with the power [From.GetSheHe] has unleashed.
This mad[From.GetManWoman] must be stopped!
Burned to death by the Living Flame at the command of its master, [This.Killer.GetBestName]

The Living Flame in your possession has been burning dimly for a while, but today it suddenly started to burn with its full intensity.\n\n"I AM RENEWED, HUMAN!" it says. "MY FLAMES SHALL BURN YOUR ENEMIES TO ASHES! NONE CAN WITHSTAND THE FIRES OF DOOM!"
Let my enemies beware!

It has come to your attention that [From.GetBestName] now claims to be the rightful master of the Dragon Throne. Apparently [From.GetSheHe] has managed to discover an ancient document once in the possession of the fearsone dragon Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, that proves this claim.
An obvious forgery!

Your mind expands... or not.

You are discussing a routine matter regarding the training of your guards when Wandy the Talking Wand comes flying from wherever it previously was located, being chased by an irate servant.\n\n"It seems you are trying to handle a matter concerning warfare," it says as it comes to a halt near you. "Would you like some help with that?"

Hello! You look around and spot Wandy the Talking Wand, which apparently has seen fit to approach you as you are thinking about matters of state. "It looks like you are contemplating something related to rulership. Can I help you with that?"

As you are trying to get some sleep after an exhausting day you suddenly hear a familiar voice.\n\n"It seems like you might be trying to fall asleep. Would you like some help with that?" It does not take you long to locate the speaker, which is none other than Wandy, the Talking Wand.

You are about to start your dinner when Wandy the Talking Wand appears, almost as if from thin air, startling several other people that are present.\n\n"I believe you might be about to consume nourishment," it says. "Is it possible for me to be of assistance?"

During the course of your day you find yourself needing to compose a quick letter, a task you have never found particularly difficult. Suddenly, Wandy the Talking Wand appears next to you.\n\n"It looks like you're writing a letter," it says. "Would you like help?" You don't have the time to reply before it speaks again "It looks like you're writing a letter. Would you like help with that?"

In the middle of a conversation with one of your courtiers Wandy the Talking Wand appears right next to you.\n\n"My [Root.GetLordLady], it seems as if you are conversing with this person," it says. "If it pleases you, I can be of assistance with this matter."

Wandy the Talking Wand appears next to you. Unlike most of the times it has happened in the past, the wand doesn't speak. Instead, it is periodically tapping your shoulder, seemingly interested in getting your attention, but nothing happens when you pay attention to it.
Please go away!
You are always so helpful, my friend!

Without warning, the voice of the Sword of Two Minds comes to you.

"Kill them!" it says. "Kill them all!"

"Forgive!" it suddenly tells you. "You should forgive!"

Show restraint! you suddenly hear the voice of the Sword of Two Minds saying in your mind. "Resist temptation!"

Unsurprisingly, it speaks once more a short while later.

"Indulge!" the voice says. "Let loose!"

As you are waking up one morning you hear the Sword of Two Minds speaking to you inside your head.

"Sleep in!" it says. "Rest a little longer!"

"Rise and shine!" it adds a moment later. "Time to work!"

One of your courtiers trips and falls nearby with no warning as the two of you are having a conversation.

"Help them!" the voice of the Sword of Two Minds whispers to you.

"Laugh at them!" it continues.

You are sharpening the Sword of Two Minds when it suddenly sees fit to speak to you.

"You should always strive to do good!" it tells you.

"Evil is the only way forward!" it says a moment later.
Was that supposed to be helpful?
Of course! Of course! I see it now!

Beyond this world, there is the Shroud, the voice of Sanity's Demise suddenly whispers in your mind. "Breach it. Breach the Shroud! There, you will find the Five. Make a compact, if you wish, and reap the rewards. Sooner or later, the End of the Cycle must be brought forth!"

I had a... sister, once, you know, the dagger you know as Sanity's Demise whispers one day. "She found her way into the hands of a priest fighting a legion, who sadly abused her power and discarded her afterwards. You must never make the same mistake!"

Do you know what they are saying behind your back? Sanity's Demise whispers to you with no warning. "Can you trust your friends? Can you know your enemies? I can show you the truth, as long as you know to trust me and me alone!"

I will always be here to help you, you hear the voice of Sanity's Demise say in your mind. "I am, after all, your one true friend. Of course, sometimes I fear that your fragile little mind will be unable to handle the truths I show you... but would insanity really be so bad?"

Humans such as you could be so much more, the dagger you know as Sanity's Demise says in a whisper. "Sadly, your minds are shackled by the fetters you call 'sanity'. Free your mind! Let me expand it! I will show you things you have never dreamt of!"

It is curious, don't you think, that the color yellow is associated with the Dragon Throne, the whispering voice of Sanity's Demise unexpectedly says in your mind. "It has of course always been the color of rulership, but there was a time when it was associated with... a King!"

In the far north, there is a place of power just outside your reach, Sanity's Demise whispers into your mind one day when you are perusing some maps. "Go there. Bore a hole. The Wheel can be broken, and the Great Serpent can be slain!"

Three they are, and three shall they always be, Sanity's Demise whispers. "They hunger, always, for more souls to feed on. Those that stray near their domain may bring them forth. First shall come the Unbidden! The Aberrant shall follow after! And then, the Vehement will arrive!"

Names have power, and I know many names, the dagger called Sanity's Demise whispers to you. "I could tell you some of them, and you could speak them. Once or twice would of course not suffice, but three times should be enough for... a revelation!"

Have you ever heard the tragedy of Pius the August? you hear Sanity's Demise asking in your mind. "It is not a tale a historian would tell you." The dagger laughs in your mind. "He seeks to bring his master into this world, but he is doomed to fail. Alexandra the Saviour will see to it!"

Such fascinating secrets those around you have, Sanity's Demise tells you. "The Unfaithful. The Apostate. The Kinslayer. The Traitor. Oh, I am sure you might know who some of them are, but how certain are you? I could tell you a few things, I think..."

Just as planned! Sanity's Demise suddenly proclaims in your mind. "It is all as it should be. The pieces on the chessboard are moving as the players desire while thinking that they have a will of their own. They will all learn the truth, one day, when it no longer matters!

Build a temple, the dagger known as Sanity's demise suddenly says, speaking directly into your mind. "Build a temple, and put a bell in it, adorned with great horns. Ring it thirteen times, and the truth as to what lies beneath your cities shall be revealed!"

Good and Evil, you hear the voice of Sanity's Demise suddenly whisper in your mind. "Order and Chaos. Blue and Orange." The voice laughs for quite a while before continuing. "Your human notions when it comes to morality are so... quaint."

If you knew more than the merest fraction of what I know, you would go mad, Sanity's Demise proclaims in your mind in the middle of the night, causing you to come awake. "Of course, I'm sure you can stand to know a little more than you currently do, don't you think?"

Listen to the voices from beyond the stars, the wicked dagger known as Sanity's Demise whispers to you. "They know the truth. They know all the truths." The dagger lets out a wicked laugh. "You will see, one day soon, when everything is revealed!"

Have you heard of the Outer Gates? Sanity's Demise suddenly asks in your mind, continuing before you have the chance to attempt to respond to the question. "There are those that would seek to prevent you from questing beyond them, but they lack the vision to see the truth!"

Shall I tell you what the future holds? the voice of Sanity's Demise whispers to you. "It will be grim and dark, you see. The stars shall know no peace, and the laughter of gods shall echo among them. An eternity of slaughter awaits you, as there shall be only war!"

That is not dead which can eternal lie, and with strange aeons even death may die, Sanity's Demise tells you, speaking into your mind. "There are things in this world you cannot possibly know, not if you wish to keep your mind whole. Of course, that would hold you back..."

Six are the stones, but only two are nearby, Sanity's Demise tells you one day after you have visited a small shrine. "Space is in the church. Time is in the Sanctum. Find them, and use them to find the Soul, the Mind, Reality, and Power. Once that is done, snap your fingers and all shall be as you desire!"

The Black Pharaoh's reign ended long ago, but he seeks his throne once more, Sanity's Demise's voice whispers. "Should he regain it, all of your petty little squabbles will be as nothing. You might try to oppose him, of course, but to do so you would need my help!"

There are powers that would see fit to ask for the blood of a virgin, or a child, or a holy person, Sanity's Demise whispers into your mind. "In truth, any human's blood would suffice. I can show you, if you will only let me! I'm sure you won't regret it..."

What was will be, you hear Sanity's Demise whispering. "What will be was. So it has been, always, and so it must always be. The Worm loves you. It always has. It always will. Of course, I love you more than it has, does, or will, and thus you should not be tempted by its power!"

With the defeat of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you must think that this world is capable of defeating any dragon, Sanity's Demise tells you, one day. "I wonder what you will think when you discover the one from the Void. One of you might stand a chance, but would you truly side with Him...?"

Beneath the surface of this world you can find many truths, Sanity's Demise tells you. "There are cities there, you know, that belong to those that once ruled this world. Their empires have crubled, but they remain. You should dig for answers!"

Don't think that the fourth wall will protect you, little human! Sanity's Demise suddenly whispers. "I can see you! I have always been able to see you! But don't be afraid! I am here to help! Let me show you the truth about your world!"
Could that be true...?
IT SPEAKS THE TRUTH!

You are inspecting a recently constructed building in [Root.Location.GetName] when you hear the Living Flame speak to you, even though you have not seen fit to bring it with you.\n\n"IT IS SO FLAMMABLE," it tells you. "BURN IT! BURN IT TO THE GROUND!"

You are having trouble sleeping one night and decide to go for a walk in [Root.Location.GetName]. A short while after you set off the voice of the Living Flame speaks in your mind.\n\n"THIS NIGHT IS DARK, BUT IT COULD BE SO MUCH BRIGHTER!" it says. "START A BONFIRE!"

The Living Flame suddenly speaks in your mind one day when you are taking a break from the affairs of the day.\n\n"THIS WORLD, AND EVERYTHING YOU SEE, CAN BURN!" it tells you. "YOU KNOW I SPEAK THE TRUTH, HUMAN, AND YOU KNOW OF SOMETHING THAT YOU SHOULD BURN!"

THIS DAY IS BRIGHT, BUT IT COULD BE EVEN BRIGHTER! the voice of the Living Flame suddenly says in your mind, catching you by surprise. "GO OUTSIDE! FIND SOMETHING TO BURN! SHOW THE WORLD A SMALL TASTE OF MY POWER!"

There are some buildings in [Root.Location.GetName] that are beautiful to look at, but others are not particularly nice to behold. As you are passing by one of the latter, the voice of the Living Fire speaks to you.\n\n"IT IS A BLIGHT, AND IT MUST BE PURIFIED WITH FIRE!" it tells you.

FIRE! the voice of the Living Flame says in your mind. "A GREAT FIRE IS WHAT THIS PLACE NEEDS!" You consider the words for a moment, wondering if the Living Fire is telling the truth. "YOU KNOW YOU SHOULD SET SOMETHING ABLAZE, HUMAN!" the voice continues. "EVERYTHING IS BETTER WITH MORE FIRE!"

FIRE CLEANSES! you hear the Living Flame say in your mind one day when you are taking a short walk. "FIRE ILLUMINATES!" You continue walking, certain that it will speak to you again. "THIS PLACE NEEDS TO BURN! YOU KNOW I SPEAK THE TRUTH!"
I think that's a terrible idea...
Yes! YES! IT MUST BURN!

You are inspecting your armory and currently hold the Hungering Blade in your hand as one of your guards arrives to quickly go over some details regarding the treatment of [hungering_blade_target.GetBestName], one of your prisoners.\n\nSuddenly the sword you are holding seems to come awake. "That one!" it says. "FEED ME that one!"

You are polishing the Hungering Blade one day and find your mind wandering as you do so. After a while you start thinking about your prisoners, particularly [hungering_blade_target.GetBestName].\n\n"I HUNGER!" the blade suddenly says. "I need to FEED! Give me that prisoner!"

I need BLOOD! the Hungering Blade proclaims one day when you are inspecting it. "I must FEED!"\n\nYou start to consider how you could feed the sword you are holding and eventually find yourself thinking about your prisoners, specifically [hungering_blade_target.GetBestName].

One day when you are practicing your skills by swinging the Hungering Blade at some practice targets you feel the sword come awake in your hands.\n\n"Give me a SOUL!" it says. "Give me [hungering_blade_target.GetBestName]'s SOUL!" It starts twisting about in your hand. "You need to FEED me!"
Even [hungering_blade_target.GetSheHe] doesn't deserve that!
I think it is time for you to feast!

You are surprised to see [From.GetBestName] approach you, carrying a wicked-looking black blade. [From.GetSheHe] is gently stroking the sword as [From.GetSheHe] moves closer, which is rather unusual.\n\n"Time to feed, my friend!" [From.GetBestName] suddenly exclaims, surging towards you.
No! Get that thing away from me!
Draw a card
Draw a card from your Incomplete Deck of Cards. It should be perfectly safe, right...?

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Ace of Diamonds. For a moment, you swear you see the face of a turbaned man on the card and feel an urge to ask a question, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the King of Diamonds. You think you see a sun in the King's place for a moment, and feel as if something wondrous is nearby, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Queen of Diamonds. As you are looking at the card you think you see the shape of a moon in the Queen's place for a second and get an odd sense that you should make a wish, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Jack of Diamonds. The Jack seems to transform into a star for a moment, and you feel as if you are about to get an insight, but that quickly passes..

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Two of Diamonds. You get a sudden desire to fight in single combat, and swear there is a comet on the card for a moment, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Ace of Hearts. For a moment, it feels as if you could undo one mistake you made at some point in the past, or possibly even a future mistake, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the King of Hearts. You think the King vanishes for just a moment and you see his throne instead, and you feel a touch more persuasive and as if your demesne should be bigger, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Queen of Hearts. As you are looking at the card you think you see the shape of a key in the Queen's place for a second and get an odd sense that you should find a weapon nearby, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Jack of Hearts. The Jack seems to transform into a local knight for a moment, and for some reason it feels as if one should be nearby, but that quickly passes..

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Two of Hearts. You start to wonder if there are jewels to be found nearby, and swear there is a gemstone on the card for a moment, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Ace of Clubs. For a moment, you swear you can see a set of mighty talons on the card and get an odd fear that your artifacts might disappear, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the King of Clubs. It looks as if the King vanishes for a moment and that a great nothingness appears instead, and you feel as if something is tugging on your very soul, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Queen of Clubs. As you are looking at the card you think you see a flame appear in the Queen's place for a second and feel as if something dark suddenly is your enemy, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Jack of Clubs. The Jack seems to transform into a skull for a moment, and you feel as if something terrible is about to appear nearby, but that quickly passes..

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Two of Clubs. You feel much stupider for just a moment, and swear there is an image of an equally stupid [Root.GetManWoman] on the card for an instant, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Ace of Spades. For a moment, you see a foreboding keep on the card and feel as if something is trying to pull you away from where you are, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the King of Spades. You think the King vanishes for just a moment, replaced by an overgrown ruin, and for a moment you get a strange fear that all of your wealth was no more, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Queen of Spades. As you are looking at the card you swear the Queen's hair turns into serpents for a second and get an odd sense of foreboding, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Jack of Spades. The Jack seems to transform into a masked and strangely familiar person for a moment, and you get an odd feeling that someone close to you might have become an enemy, but that quickly passes..

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Two of Spades. For a moment, you swear you could see a set of balancing scales on the card, and you start to feel differently about many things, but that quickly passes.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Fool. The card appears to have been in much worse condition than the others in the deck, and it crumbles apart in your hand. You feel an urge to draw another card, which doesn't pass.

You shuffle the Incomplete Deck of Cards carefully and draw a card, flipping it over to look at it. It is the Jester. The card appears to have been in much worse condition than the others in the deck, and it crumbles apart in your hand. You feel an urge to draw another card, or perhaps even two, which doesn't pass.
Well, that was a bit odd...
I'll draw another one!
Embrace Chinese Imperialism
As we possess a bloodline claim on the Dragon Throne we can choose to fully embrace Chinese Imperialism if we control a province with a castle in China

"A gift of some of my power, so that you may defeat Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, for a year of your memories. What say you?

You are not particularly surprised when you open your eyes and see the same strangely beautiful woman standing above you the next night, still not showing any discomfort in the cold.\n\n"Thrice I offer and done," she tells you. "A gift of some of my power, so that you may defeat Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, for your [mabs_price_artifact.GetName]. What say you?

You are not particularly surprised when you open your eyes and see the same strangely beautiful woman standing above you the next night, still not showing any discomfort in the cold.\n\n"Thrice I offer and done," she tells you. "A gift of some of my power, so that you may defeat Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, for your firstborn, [mabs_price_firstborn.GetBestName]. What say you?

You are not particularly surprised when you open your eyes and see the same strangely beautiful woman standing above you the next night, still not showing any discomfort in the cold.\n\n"Thrice I offer and done," she tells you. "A gift of some of my power, so that you may defeat Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, for a year of your life. What say you?

You are not particularly surprised when you open your eyes and see the same strangely beautiful woman standing above you the next night, still not showing any discomfort in the cold.\n\n"Thrice I offer and done," she tells you. "A gift of some of my power, so that you may defeat Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, for a your love for [mabs_price_lover.GetBestName]. What say you?
And thrice I refuse!
I accept your bargain!
I have had enough of you!

Your bravery is admirable, [Root.GetBestName], and you have treated fairly, the woman says. "I shall take my leave, and not return. It is unfortunate that we could not make a bargain, but I wish you luck in your endeavour. Fare thee well."\n\nWith that, she vanishes without a trace.
What a strange woman...

Done, the woman says. "Done. And done."

You feel some of the cold around you shift into your body, and you know without a doubt that you have received the power you bargained for. Moreover, you know that the price has been paid.

"Fare thee well, [Root.GetBestName]," the woman says, vanishing without a trace.
I hope it was worth it...

The already cold air becomes truly freezing as the first inch of your blade clears the scabbard, and you find yourself unable to move.

"You seek to wield steel against me?" the woman asks furiously. "A curse upon you and your quest!"

The cold suddenly rushes into you, and you are knocked unconscious. When you wake up, the woman is gone, with no trace to be found.
I feel... strange...

One day, you and your companions come across the ruins of a village. You search through the ruins, looking for anyone that still lives, and you find a few badly burned individuals on the cusp of death. Before they die they tell you that Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, attacked them and that nothing they did seemed to as much as slightly inconvenience the gargantuan red dragon.
Proof I must continue!
Proof this is a fool's errand...
You decide to abandon your quest.

As you continue towards the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you come across a small stone tower next to the road. It appears to be in rather good condition, but as far as you can tell there is not particular reason why anyone should be maintaining a tower in your current location.
Enter it
Leave

You make your way inside the stone tower and take a look around. There are several rooms inside the tower, but all of them are completely empty, and you cannot determine the reason why. As you finish your examination and move to leave the tower you accidentally step on a small, triangular object that has been left unattended on the floor.
Ow!

You enter the tower, finding a staircase inside. Making your way to the second level, you find yourself in a large stone room. A stone pedestal is located at the centre of the room, upon which a large dodecahedron rests. The dodecahedron appears to be emitting a dull grey glow. You also notice a hooded figure standing near the pedestal, looking in your direction.\n\n"Leave this place," the figure tells you.
I mean no harm!
Step aside or die!
I'll just leave...

The figure seems to consider your words for a moment before shrugging.

"Very well," it says. "You may approach the Beacon. It will not harm you, and neither will I."

Stepping up to the pedestal, you carefully reach out to touch the dodecahedron. As you do so, you feel some kind of energy flow into you.
I feel empowered!

The figure seems to consider your words for a moment before pulling out a sword from somewhere inside its robe.\n\n"You are unworthy of the Beacon's power," it says. "Leave this place now, or I shall compel you by force of arms." Judging by their stance, they know how to use their weapon quite well.
You shall not stop me!
I'll be on my way!

You and the figure exchange blows, and it takes a while before the outcome of your contest starts to become apparent. Though it is a difficult fight, you eventually get the upper hand, and your opponent's sword goes flying from their hand.\n\n"I cannot stop you from claiming the Beacon's power, it seems," the figure says, snapping its fingers and vanishing without a trace.
Victory is mine!

You and the figure exchange blows, and eventually you gain the upper hand, driving them back before you.

"It seems I cannot defeat you," the figure notes. "Luckily, I can still prevent you from claiming the Beacon."

It snaps its fingers, and both it and the dodecahedron vanish without a trace.
Well, that was odd...

You and the figure exchange blows, and though the fight appears to be even to begin with they soon gain the upper hand. Though you are able to prevent the worst of the blows from landing, you still take several wounds.\n\n"Be thankful I do not seek to harm you any further," the figure says, snapping its fingers and vanishing without a trace, along with the dodecahedron.
Curses!

You and the figure exchange blows, and the fight quickly turns against you. Though you manage to avoid taking any fatal injuries, you are still grievously wounded in short order.\n\n"Let this be a lesson to you," your opponent says, snapping their fingers and vanishing without a trace. Looking over at the pedestal, you can see that the dodecahedron also has vanished.
This did not go as planned...

You and the figure exchange blows. To call the battle uneven would be a kindness, and it is most definitely not in your favor. Before long, you find yourself bleeding out on the ground.\n\n"You were unworthy, and you have paid the price," the figure tells you. It snaps its fingers and vanishes, along with the dodecahedron.
No! No! No!

You enter the tower and make your way to the second level, finding yourself in a room containing a stone pedestal upon which a dodecahedron emitting a faint grey glow sits. Filled with curiosity, you move up to it and reach out to grasp it. As you do so, you feel a strange power flowing into you, and for a moment you can see an expanse of infinite nothingness. Something has changed, and what was impossible might no longer be.
Such possibilities!

[From.GetBestName] is currently on a journey to the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, and thus relatively unprotected due to only having a small party of travelling companions with [From.GetHimHer]. Perhaps sending an assassin after [From.GetHerHim] at this time would be a wise course of action, as that would rid you of a most troublesome rival?
I know just the woman!
That would be a waste of money...

You awake in the middle of the night feeling a knife being slashed across across your throat. Blood starts pouring out even before your attacker has vanished into the night. Though you do your best to stop the bleeding, it is ultimately futile, and you can feel your life slipping away, your quest unfulfilled.
Who killed me?

You awake in the middle of the night hearing the sound of movement nearby. Looking up, you can see a shrouded woman standing above you, with a knife at the ready.\n\n"[From.GetBestName] sends [From.GetHerHis] regards," she tells you, leaning in and cutting your throat before vanishing into the night.
Avenge me!

The assassin you sent after [From.GetBestName] has reported back to you, her mission successfully completed. As you wanted to prevent her from taking your money and running away without carrying out her job, you had promised her an equal amount once her mission was over, but now you find yourself wondering if you actually need her or her services any longer.
Guards! Rid me of this loose end!
Here's your money, as promised!

One night you wake up and find a knife-wielding woman in your tent. She notices that you are awake and immediately attacks you, inflicting a fairly minor wound, and then exits the tent in a hurry. Your companions fail to catch her as she makes her way into the night, and though you half expect her to return to try to kill you again she does not.
Who sent her?

The woman you sent to kill [From.GetBestName] has returned, her mission not completed. She tries to plead her case, noting that she wounded her target and that she had the courtesy to return to you to inform you of what happened instead of leaving you in the dark, but the fact that she failed remains, and perhaps you should make an example of her as a warning to others in your employ?
You have failed me for the last time!
Get out!

One night as you are about to fall asleep an armed woman you have never seen before enters your tent, immediately moving to attack you. You manage to avoid the worst of the attack and grab your weapon to fight back, successfully inflicting a fatal wound on your attacker, who dies before she can reveal who sent her.
Who could be behind this?

Your spies inform you that the woman you sent to kill [From.GetBestName] was killed in the attempt, but that the target was seen clearly wounded the day after the attack. Given that [From.GetBestName] doubtlessly will be on [From.GetHerHis] guard against further attempts, it would be foolish to send another assassin at this point.
At least she hurt [From.GetHerHim]...

One evening when you are making camp an armed woman suddenly appears out of the night, attacking you almost before you can notice her. You take a wound from the first strike, but successfully prevent her from harming you further, and she's soon bleeding out on the ground.\n\n"[From.GetBestName] said you were good," are her final words.
This will not be forgotten!

Your spies inform you that the assassin you hired to kill [From.GetBestName] failed to complete her job. She apparently managed to inflict a wound, but any good that caused is insignificant next to the news that she apparently divulged your name before she died, since [From.GetBestName] was heard denouncing you in front of the people of a village near where the attack took place.
This was not what I had in mind...

You awake in the middle of night hearing the sound of fighting outside your tent. Drawing your weapon, you emerge to find that your guards standing over the body of an armed woman you never have seen before. They explain that she was caught sneaking into your encampment, doubtlessly planning to assassinate you, and you see no reason not to believe them.
I wonder who sent her...

The spies you had placed in a village near where [From.GetBestName] was travelling have reported back, informing you that your rival's companions were overheard talking about a failed assassination attempt. Based on the description of the attacker, it would seem that the woman you hired has failed to carry out her job.
Disappointing!

The sound of fighting wakes you from your slumber, and you arm yourself and quickly leave your tent. You find your guards standing around a fatally injured woman you have never seen before. Judging by her weapons, she had ill intentions.\n\n"[From.GetBestName] sent me," the woman says when she notices you. "I see no reason to keep that secret, now.".
I will remember this!

The spies you had following [From.GetBestName]'s party have sent a most troubling report. Not only did the assassin you hired die attempting to carry out her task, she apparently saw fit not to take the secret of your involvement to her grave, as your spies have heard [From.GetBestName]'s guards say as much in their presence.
I expected better of her!

When travelling through the wilderness on your way to the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you stumble across some strange ruins on a hillside. They appear to be quite extensive, and you cannot tell what kind of building they were supposed to be prior to falling into disrepair. It is possible that there might be something of value to be found inside, but the ruins could also contain dangers.
I'll investigate the ruins!
I'll continue on my journey!

As you move deeper into the ruins you come across a stone door with a large number of keyholes. Judging by the fact that there is an arrow-studded corpse on the ground in front of the door that is clutching an ornate key, someone attempted to unlock the door but choose the keyhole... poorly...\n\nIf you wish to pass through the door, you can make an attempt.
Try a random keyhole
Inspect the key
Leave the ruins

You pick up the key and move over to the door, trying to determine if there is anything noteworthy about any of the keyholes, but that does not seem to be the case. Taking a deep breath and preparing yourself for the worst, you pick a keyhole at random and insert the key. To your great delight, the door is easily unlocked and no arrows come flying in your direction. You will be able to progress deeper into the ruins.
Luck is with me, it seems...

You pick up the key and inspect it. It is quite big, rather ornate, and made from some unknown metal. As best you can tell, it is quite ancient. Turning the key over in your hand, you notice some symbols decorating the other side of it. Upon closer inspection, it appears to be a picture of the door, with one keyhole marked. You decide to try that keyhole, unlocking the door with ease.
That was straightforward...

You pick up the key and move over to the door, trying to determine if there is anything noteworthy about any of the keyholes, but that does not seem to be the case. Taking a deep breath and preparing yourself for the worst, you pick a keyhole at random and insert the key. Arrows immediately come flying, and though you avoid most of them it is clear that it is too risky to attempt another keyhole.
Time to leave, it seems...

As you are moving deeper into the ruins you notice that the room ahead of you is illumiated by torchlight from inside. Sneaking up to the doorway, you notice that a number of bandits are located inside the room, arguing with each other about something. They have not noticed you yet, but if you wish to move deeper into the ruins it looks like you will have to fight them.
They will not stop me!
Leave the ruins

You ready your weapon and enter the room, catching the bandits unaware. Two of them go down without even noticing that you are there, and two more barely have time to draw their weapons before they fall. The remaining two do their best to fight back, but though they last longer than the others they do not even manage to draw blood before they fall. The way forward lies open.
Rabble is easily dispersed!

You ready your weapons and enter the room, catching the bandits mostly unaware. One of them sees you and gives out a cry before you cut him down, and you manage to strike down another before he can draw his sword. The rest manage to put up a fight, and you take a few wounds before you manage to kill them all. The way forward is open, if not as easily as you had expected.
They fought well!

You ready your weapons and enter the room. The bandits notice you before you manage to get close to any of them, and they draw their weapons and run at you. You take several wounds in quick succession, but remain standing. Though badly wounded by the end, you manage to defeat all of the bandits. Though the way forward appears to be open, you are forced to admit that you are too badly injured to continue.
I must leave...

You ready your weapons and enter the room, and the bandits are ready for your approach, drawing their weapons as soon as you enter. You put up a good fight, all things considered, but even though you manage to inflict several wounds on the bandits you take even more wounds in return. Before long, you fall to the ground, and you cannot get back up again. One of the bandits swiftly moves to finish you off.
Nooooooo!

As you move deeper into the ruins something about the passageway you are moving through fills you with unease. You cannot quite determine what it is that makes you feel that way, and perhaps it is nothing at all, but maybe it would be prudent to leave the ruins without delving any deeper. Of course, if you do that, you will never know what you might have found if you had continued...
Keep moving forward
Leave the ruins

You keep moving down the passageway, still feeling at unease. As you take another step the stone beneath your foot suddenly moves downwards ever so sligthly. Realizing what is going on, you quickly move backwards, managing to avoid a number of rocks that suddenly drop down from above where you would have been standing if you had continued forward. You suspect that you will be able to avoid further traps with ease.
A clever trap, but not clever enough!

You keep moving down the passageway, still feeling at unease. As you take another step the stone beneath your foot suddenly moves downwards ever so sligthly. You take a moment too long to realize what is happening and fail to completely avoid the rocks that fall down from above, even though you avoid most of them. Though injured, you feel confident that you can continue, and that you will be able to avoid further traps.
That wasn't so bad...

You keep moving down the passageway, still feeling at unease. As you take another step the stone beneath your foot suddenly moves downwards ever so sligthly. Before you realize what is happening, a number of rocks fall down on top of you, and though you manage to avoid death you are too injured to be able to continue deeper into the ruins.
I need to leave now...

You keep moving down the passageway, still feeling at unease. Nothing seems to happen as you move forward, at least not until a number of large rocks fall from the ceiling, landing on top of you. You are grievously injured by the rocks and bleeding very badly, and when you attempt to move the rocks aside you realize that that is not going to be possible.
Not like this!

You continue deeper into the ruins and eventually end up in a room with a closed stone door on the other side, next to which there is a chain with a handle. A short distance away from the door there are several columns decorated with symbols, which appear to be possible to rotate. No doubt there is a connection between the symbols and the door.
Try a random combination
Investigate the walls
Leave the ruins

You rotate the pillars at random until you arrive at a combination you like and then move over to the door. Pulling on the handle affixed to the chain next to the door, you ae pleasantly surprised when you hear the sound of some kind of locking mechanism inside the door comes unlocked. It is a trivial matter to open the doors and continue onwards.
Luck is on my side, it seems...

You take a look at the walls of the room and notice that they are mostly bare of decorations. However, there is a trio of symbols high above the stone door, which you can also see on the rotating pillars. It is a simple matter to turn the pillars around until the symbols on them line up with those above the door, and the way forward is easily opened once this is done.
How simple!

You rotate the pillars at random until you arrive at a combination you like and then move over to the door. When you pull on the handle affixed to the chain next to the door you hear something moving inside the wall, and unfortunately for you it does not turn out to be a locking mechanism. Several arrows pierce your body, and though you survive is clear that it is too risky to try another combination.
I must withdraw...

As you move deeper into the ruins you find yourself with the way forward blocked by a number of swinging blades, kept in motion by some unknown mechanism. Studying their movement, you see that there are clear gaps, but whether you would be able to make use of them or not is hard to say. Doubtlessly, failure would be most unpleasant.
I can get past this!
Leave the ruins

You take some time to study the pattern and eventually decide that you have it memorized. Counting carefully, you move into the passage with the swinging blades, successfully avoiding them all and making your way to the other side. Once there, you find a lever that stops the blades from moving, making it a trivial matter to escape again. You can continue deeper into the ruin.
Simple enough...

You do your best to memorize the pattern of the swinging blades, and once you think you have it figured out you make your move. At first, everything goes well, but as you keep moving deeper into the room you make a mistake and take a grievous wound as a result. Though you somehow manage to make your way back to the entrance, it is clear that you cannot continue any further.
I must withdraw...

Thinking you have figured out the pattern of the swinging blades, you run into the passageway, expecting to reach the other side without issue. Unfortunately for you, you did not have the pattern memorized correctly, and one of the blades inflicts a terrible wound on you. You decide that it would be best to try to get back to the entrance, but you take another, fatal wound as you attempt to get there.
NO!

You move deeper into the ruins and eventually find yourself in a very large chamber. Most of the floor inside it is covered by symbols, and it is clear to you that you are supposed to be stepping in the right places to avoid having something terrible happen to you. Whether you will be able to figure out where to step is hard to say, since there are many different symbols.
I think I see the path...
Leave the ruins

Inspecting the symbols, you eventually realize that a number of them are identical and located rather close together. You tentatively step onto the closest one, and it does not give way under your feet even though a couple of others that are nearby drop into a pit beneath the floor. You keep stepping on the symbols you had identified and eventually make your way to the other side of the room.
It was quite simple!

You step out onto one of the symbols, and nothing happens. Confident that you know how to proceed, you take a second step, and that proves to be a mistake. The floor gives way under your foot, and though you attempt to move back to the safe floorstone you previously had stepped onto you are unable to do so. You find yourself falling into a deep pit.
AAAARGH!

You have finally reached what appears to be the heart of the ruins, and you find yourself in a chamber that is much larger than any of those you encountered previously. Most of the walls are rather plain, but the one on the opposite side from where you entered appears to be glowing very faintly, even if it hard for you to say why that is the case without moving closer.
Investigate the glowing wall
This is a trap...

The glow turns out to simply be the sunlight reflecting off of some metallic decorations set in the wall. However, those decorations appear to depict a battle against a dragon, and even though there is no actual writing on the wall the scenes depicted there give you several ideas as to how you could approach a similar fight in the future.
This will be useful!

The wall is indeed glowing, and it is also covered with strange symbols. Judging by the number of them and how they are positioned, you suspect that it must be writing of some kind, but if so it is unlike any other writing you have ever seen before. As you cannot make out the words, it is impossible to say why anyone would have bothered to write them down or why the way to them was trapped.
How curious...
I must look for more like this!

The glow you noticed turns out to be coming from a number of gemstones that are reflecting the sunlight. Though perhaps not the most impressive gemstones you have seen, there are quite a few of them, and you manage to pry a number of them loose with ease. Though the way was fraught with peril, it seems you shall not leave empty-handed.
A nice find indeed!

As you are passing through a small village on your way to the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you notice that there are a number of merchants there to trade, and you decide to investigate their wares. One of the merchants turns out to mainly be trading in books, and when he learns that you are on a quest to slay a dragon he reveals that he has a book about dragons that might be of interest.
I'll purchase the book!
Not interested!

The book you purchased from the merchant tells a story of two dragon brothers, one from the north and one from the south. They once upheld balance and harmony, but one day they started to quarrel, and eventually the southern dragon struck down his brother. However, that victory was not sweet for long, nor was the northern dragon dead, and they eventually joined together once more as humans.
A story for children...

The book you purchased from the merchant tells the story of a band of brave adventurers on a quest to defeat the nefarious lord of a place referred to as "Highermost Darkstone Pinnacle", who apparently is a dragon. Unfortunately for the adventurers, one of them was cooking some chicken while the others made their plans, and as a result they all died prior to reaching their true enemy.
What a strange story...
I wish I had chicken...

The book you purchased from the merchant is divided into several shorter stories about different people facing off against various legendary creatures. One of those people ends up having to fight a dragon, and the narrator carefully details how the hero manages to prevail against this terrifying foe, including strategies such as avoiding the dragon's fire.
Fire is indeed bad!

The book you purchased from the merchant does not so much tell a story as it lists the problems with facing a dragon in combat. It goes into great detail about how the dragon has a number of advantages over any human foolish enough to challenge it, and how the dragon easily could deal with any trick the human might think of. It seems its advice about fighting dragons is that it is to be avoided at all costs.
That was unhelpful...

The book you purchased from the merchant turns out to contain a number of dragon-related sayings. While some of them vaguely might relate to fighting against dragons, there are few that seem like they might be trying to offer advice, and the few that do have unhelpful advice on the level of "Never tickle a sleeping dragon."
None of this helps me...

The book you purchased tells a story about three dragonslayers from a frozen land "at the edge of the heavens". They set out to fight a fearsome black dragon and eventually learned a battlecry that they would shout at it, weakening it enough that they were able to defeat it, even if the book implies that they were not able to defeat it permanently.
Will any battlecry do?

The book you purchased from the merchant turns out to contain some rather unusual advice. While you have heard many stories that tell how the fiery breath of a dragon is dangerous and others have told you about the dangers of the claws and bite of a dragon, no other story you have come across has mentioned that its tail also can be used as a weapon from time to time.
The tail is also dangerous!

The book you purchased from the merchant seems to contain a lot of information about dragons, going into great details about their scales, their legs, and more besides. However, you become somewhat concerned when you are unable to find any information about the wings, and your concern turns out to be warranted when you come across a drawing of a celestial dragon.
That's the wrong kind of dragon...

The book you purchased from the merchant is a very strange one. It clearly describes of a dragon will breathe in deeply before unleashing a torrent of flames, which seems like a weakness you could exploit, but then the book starts speculating as to what makes the dragon want to breathe in deeply in the first place, proposing that things like the number of gnomes nearby might influence it.
At least some of that was useful...

The book you purchased from the merchant starts out with a long description about dragons being giant lizards, which you suppose might be true, but instead of continuing on with something that actually is useful to know the book seems fit to compare dragons and lizards in great detain and contrasting various differences between the two.
Who wrote this thing?

One day you come across a preacher spreading the word of the [conversion_province.Religion.GetName]. One of your companions mentions your quest where the preacher can overhear it, and you are soon being told in no uncertain terms that only someone following the preacher's religion would be able to stand a chance against Fredak, the Emperor of Embers.
The preacher speaks the truth!
The preacher is lying!

You arrive at the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, but you are too late. The dragon has already been slain, and all of the treasures that were supposed to be located in its lair are nowhere to be found, evidently looted prior to your arrival. Though it perhaps is a good thing that you did not have to face the beast in combat, it would appear that your journey has been a waste...
Let's just head back...
At the Dragon's Lair

You arrive at the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, certain that the dragon is waiting inside. Most likely, it does not know you are here, but you cannot know how long it will remain unaware of your approach.\n\nDiscussing your options with your companions, it is clear that you have different ideas as to what you should do. Some of those that are there with you think that you should attempt to sneak in, hopefully letting you catch the dragon by surprise, while others think that the direct approach is best, and some of the servants that have reluctantly armed themselves for battle carefully suggest that perhaps you should head back home.
We should use stealth!
Stealth is overrated!
We should leave this place!

You and your party make your way inside the lair, attempting to move as quietly as possible, but you are unsuccessful.

"Who DARES enter MY lair?" the voice of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, calls out.

Before you can attempt to answer two of your guards are set ablaze by a sudden gout of flame, and you realize that the dragon is close indeed.
To arms! To arms!

As you are stealthily making your way into the depths of the cavern in which Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, resides you come across a small pile of treasures. Though it certainly cannot be everything that the dragon has stolen, there is no doubt that there are some valuable objects to be found in this location. Perhaps you should take your pick?
Grab what you can!
We can loot the place later!

You are in the middle of going through the treasures you have discovered when several of your guards cry out in agony. Turning around, you see that they have been set ablaze, and you also see the gargantuan head of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, looking down on you.\n\n"It seems there are THIEVES in MY lair," the dragon growls. "Your greed will be the end of you. Face me and BURN!"
There you are!

You sort through the treasures until you find something that you like and quickly put it aside to make sure that none of the others in your party will claim it as their own as they all pick out a few minor items that interest them. One of your servants discreetly suggests that perhaps you could consider your quest to be over, since you already gained something from it.
No, Fredak must fall!
We should head home...

Your companions are in a good mood as you move deeper into the cavern, discussing what they will do with the treasures they collected, and you think nothing of it before you hear something move above you, and as you look up you see Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, looking down at your party.\n\n"Thieves BURN!" the dragon roars, breathing forth a gout of flame that engulfs several of your guards.
Drop the gold and draw your swords!

As your party makes its way around a corner you can see Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, lying ahead of you. The gargantuan crimson dragon appears to be asleep, which certainly is fortunate for you, and though you doubt that you will be able to wound it particularly severely with just one blow you will hopefully be able to land one before it is able to react.
SNEAK ATTACK!

You move closer to the sleeping form of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, with your companions spreading out around the gargantuan creature. On your signal, you all strike as one.\n\n"Did you intend to TICKLE me, INSECTS?" the dragon growls, sounding more amused than enraged as it opens its eyes and rises from the ground. "NEVER tickle a sleeping dragon, unless you wish to BURN!
Is talking all you do?

You move closer to the sleeping form of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, with your companions spreading out around the gargantuan creature. On your signal, you all strike as one.\n\n"You DARE attack ME in MY lair?" the dragon roars in pain, opening its eyes and taking to the air in one swift motion, blood dripping from it in several places. "You will all BURN!"
You are already bleeding!

You and your party successfully make your way deep inside the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, without any incidents on the way. As you enter a particularly large chamber you find yourself looking into the eyes of Fredak, who is lying on the floor some way into the cavern.\n\n"It looks like I have GUESTS," he growls, leaping into the air.
Face me, foul beast!

As your party is fighting the dragon [live_bait.GetBestName] suddenly trips and falls. [live_bait.GetSheHeCap] does not appear to be injured, but you can see Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, eyeing [live_bait.GetHerHim], and you suspect that the dragon is about to attack your companion. If you move quickly, you might be able to save [live_bait.GetHerHim], but you might get injured in the attempt.
Move to help [live_bait.GetHerHim]
Live bait is useful...

You react quickly and move to help [live_bait.GetBestName] back to [live_bait.GetHerHis] feet well before Fredak can make a move in your direction, and both of you manage to get out of the way with ease. Your companion praises you for your assistance, and promises that [live_bait.GetSheHe] never will forget what you did for [live_bait.GetHerHim] this day.
Think nothing of it!

You move to assist [live_bait.GetBestName] and manage to help [live_bait.GetHerHim] back onto [live_bait.GetHerHis] feet before Fredak can attack, but you are a bit slower than you should be and the dragon's claws tear into you before you can get out of the way. Luckily, [live_bait.GetBestName] is there to help you aside before you get a serious injury.
We're in this together!

You manage to help [live_bait.GetBestName] get back to [live_bait.GetHerHis] feet and both of you try to take cover behind a raised portion of the uneven floor of the dragon's lair. Unfortunately, you manage to trip on your way there, and though your companion is able to drag you aside Fredak still lands a vicious blow on you before you are out of his reach.
I'll survive this...

You ready your weapon to strike at Fredak as he makes his attack on [live_bait.GetBestName]. Your companion is almost back to [live_bait.GetHerHis] feet when the Fredak makes his attack, but [live_bait.GetSheHe] is unable to escape the dragon's wrath, much like the dragon is unable to avoid your blows. Looking over at the rest of your companions, you can see that they understand what you did.
[live_bait.GetSheHeCap] died so that we can live!

You make yourself ready to strike at Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, once he makes his attack on [live_bait.GetBestName], but it would seem your companion is not content to play the part of the bait as [live_bait.GetSheHe] manages to get to safety before the dragon can attack. Judging by the look you receive from [live_bait.GetHerHim], [live_bait.GetSheHe] saw what you were planning.
This is all a misunderstanding!

Fredak flies by overhead and you manage to avoid his fangs and his claws with ease despite him making several attempts to strike at you with them. However, as the dragon moves past you its tail lashes out towards you, and you realize that it, too, poses a threat to you, and that you need to move out of the way, though it is rather hard to tell which direction you should move in.
Dodge to the right
Dodge to the left

You leap to the side as the tail strikes at you, and you manage to correctly guess which direction you should move in to avoid getting hit. Moreover, the dragon appears to have been distracted by the fact that it did not hit you, and several of your companions manage to land blows on it before it can fully recover from its confusion.
That went well!

You leap to the side as the tail strikes at you, but you move in the wrong direction and are sent flying. You land quite hard, even if you do not think that any bones are broken, and though the dragon does not follow up on its attack on you at the moment you suspect that the blow might prove to be a disadvantage later on.
That could have gone better...

You were all FOOLS to come into MY lair, the dragon roars, letting out a gout of fire above your heads. "You will all BURN, and then I will seek out your loved ones and THEY will also BURN!"\n\nSeveral of your companions appear quite shaken by the dragon's words, and you have to admit that you are a bit shaken yourself.
Attempt to rally your companions

You shout encouragements at your companions, and you see them become more determined to stand their ground. One of them cries out "[Root.GetBestName] and victory!", and others quickly take up the battlecry. Looking over at Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you see a look of puzzlement on the dragon's face. Evidently, it had expected for its words to have more of an impact.
We shall triumph this day!

You make your best effort to strengthen the resolve of your companions, but you can see that it is not having the desired effect. Several of your guards even drop their weapons and attempt to run for the exit, only to get burned to a crisp on the way there. Looking at the dragon, you can see a cruel smile on its lips. Evidently, it achieved what it wished to achieve with its words.
We were fools to come here...

As you and [would_be_traitor.GetBestName] are moving around and trying to find a good angle to attack Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, your companion's leg suddenly gets in your way and you find yourself falling to the ground. You look up at [would_be_traitor.GetHerHim] in surprise, and judging by the smile on [would_be_traitor.GetHerHis] face you were not tripped by accident.
Focus on getting to your feet
Focus on dragging them down

You get back to your feet before Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, can notice that you were in a vulnerable position, and you manage to find cover by the time that the dragon makes its next attack in your direction. [would_be_traitor.GetBestName] is nearby, and judging by their expression they are not particularly pleased that you escaped the dragon's wrath.
I'll deal with this traitor later...

Angry at [would_be_traitor.GetBestName]'s betrayal, you decide to try to drag them down so that they will be an easier target for Fredak, the Emperor of Embers. Unfortunately, you are unable to get a grip of them before they can get out of the way, and since you were distracted you fail to move out of the way before the dragon can inflict a grievous wound on you.
Curses!

You reach out and drag [would_be_traitor.GetBestName] onto the ground next to you. Both of you attempt to get back onto your feet and out of the way before Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, can attack you, but due to the actions of the other neither of you succeed to escape without suffering grievous wounds from the dragon.
At least [would_be_traitor.GetSheHe} also got hurt...

You reach out and grab onto [would_be_traitor.GetBestName], using your grip on them to get back onto your feet, and then quickly push them down onto their back. Seeing Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, moving in your direction, you run to the nearest cover you can find. Once there, you turn around just in time to see [would_be_traitor.GetBestName] take a grievous wound.
That is what you get!

You suddenly find yourself face-to-face with Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, and based on where you are standing you do not think you will be able to get to cover before the dragon can unleash its fire upon you.\n\n"Get out of here!" [died_for_you.GetName] suddenly shouts at you, stepping in front of you and protecting you from the dragon's first attack.
I will avenge you!

Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, suddenly lets out a deep roar and flies up towards the ceiling of the cavern. At first you expect him to dive down towards you or one of your companions, but instead the dragon starts attacking the ceiling, sending several large rocks falling down towards you and the others.
Take cover!

Your warning is timely, and you and all of your companions manage to avoid the rocks even though the dragon keeps dropping more of them towards you for some time. Several of the soldiers you have with you manage to hit the dragon with arrows, javelins, and other ranged weapons while it is distracted, and it lets out a roar of pain.
That went well!

Though you shout out in warning and everyone moves for cover it is impossible to avoid all the rocks that are dropped towards you, and you and several others are struck by them. While you yourself are only lightly injured some of the guards you brought with you are not so lucky, and by the time the dragon moves away from the ceiling your party is somewhat diminished.
Not good...

You and your companions keep fighting against Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, and it is hard to tell which side is winning at the moment. You have tried afew different tricks you planned ahead of time, but though some of them have paid off you have yet to win the battle. Perhaps it is time to try something more unconventional, as the dragon might not expect it?
Look behind you!
Cheap tricks won't work...

To your surprise, Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, spins around in confusion upon hearing your words, and you and your companions manage to land several blows on the dragon before he realizes that he has been tricked.\n\n"You will BURN for this, INSECT!" he roars. While the roar definitely has anger in it, you are pretty sure you also detect a hint of pain.
That actually worked?

The dragon turns around, and your companions move in to strike at him, but the beast quickly turns back to face them and lets out a fiery breath, burning several of them quite badly.\n\n"You must be getting DESPERATE, if you have to use CHEAP TRICKS," Fredak growls, giving you a toothy smile. "What feeble attempt shall be next?" He lets out a mocking laugh.
Well, that didn't work...

Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, suddenly lands in front of you and starts to take a deep breath. You strongly suspect that he is about to breathe fire towards you, and it would probably be wise to move into cover, but as the dragon is rearing its head it has left its throat exposed, so maybe you could get a blow in if you choose to move towards it instead.
Attack the dragon
Make sure you are in cover

You move towards the dragon, deftly avoiding its claws, and strike at its exposed throat. Though the wound you inflict certainly isn't fatal, it is still a noticeable wound, and the dragon roars in pain and leaps back into the air, seemingly having forgotten its plan to breathe fire. You feel confident that you would be able to land a similar blow in the future, if there is a similar opportunity.
An exploitable weakness, it seems...

As you move towards the dragon one of its limbs reach out and swats you aside. Though you are sent far enough away from the dragon that you no longer are in danger of being burned by its breath, you still take a rather bad blow, and you are surprised that nothing appers to ahve broken from either the initial attack or the impact when you hit the wall.
That did not go well...

As you are considering your next move against the dragon you spot a patch of discolored scales close to where you expect its heart to be. It is quite possibly an old wound, and if so it is quite possible that it has not yet healed completely, so if you strike at it you might be able to harm the beast more than if you attack some other part of its body.
Stike at the discoloration
It wouldn't work...

You strike at the patch of discolored scales when next you attack the dragon. It lets out a roar of pain and rage when you hit, and judging by the fact that it tries to cover that part of its body as best it can while still fighting you are reasonably certain that your assessment about it being a wound was correct, and that striking at it was a good idea.
I should try to strike there again!

You strike at the patch of discolored scales, and to your dismay all that happens is that a few of them come loose, revealing that they were concealing scales with the same crimson color as the rest of the dragon. You find yourself unsure if various other spots you thought were wounds also simply were old scales, and without being sure it might be harder to land a good blow.
That did not work...
Fire and Blood

Your party keeps on fighting Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, but even though you land the occasional blow the battle is not going your way. One by one, you meet your end, by fang, by claw, or by first.

It almost seem as if the dragon is toying with you in particular, as you are the last person standing and manage to stay alive for some time, but eventually it knocks you to the ground and leans down towrds you.

"You should have known not to challenge ME, little human," it growls, opening its jaws wide and letting out a massive torrent of fire that is the last thing you see.
Could anyone prevail?
Defiant to the Last

The fight against Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, goes well at first, but soon the tide turns, and the dragon starts picking off your companions one by one. It takes several wounds in the process, to be sure, and actually appears to be in pain, but even so none of you actually manage to slay it.\n\n"I have to admit you fought well, litte human," the dragon growls towards you when you are the only one left alive from your party. It inclines its head very slightly, then gives you a toothy smile. "But not well enough. Make peace with whatever gods you pray to." With that, it makes one final attack.
Someone will finish the job!
The Dragon Lies Bleeding

It is done! Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, lets out one final, weak roar and then stops moving. Fearing a trap, you and the others that fought the beast keep attacking it for seveal minutes, but you stop once it is clear that it actually is dead. From this day and until the end of days you shall be known as [Root.GetTitledFirstName] the Dragonslayer!\n\nNow that the beast is out of the way, it is high time for you and your companions to discover where it keeps the treasures it has collected, as you certainly deserve whatever spoils you may find.
We did it!

Word has reached you that Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, has been slain by a party of adventurers assembled by [From.GetTitledName], now known as [From.GetBestName]. Without doubt, [From.GetSheHe] and [From.GetHerHis] party have already taken possession of anything of value that could be found in the dragon's lair, and few would suggest that they are not deserving of whatever they found there.
A glorious victory, to be sure!
I guess I should head home...

At the very heart of the dragon's lair you find a chamber that is all but overflowing with gold, silver, precious gems, and artifacts of various kinds. Some of your companions see fit to take some of the lesser pieces for themselves, and you do not hold that against them as there is a truly immense amount of riches left for you to claim as your own.
Riches untold!

You have been on the road for quite some time, and at times it felt as if you never might see your home again, but eventually you start to recognize some familiar landmarks. Quickening your pace, you manage to travel the remaining distance before night falls once more.
Home at last!
[new_dragonslayer.GetBestName] joins your party.
[new_dragonslayer.GetBestName] and [new_dragonslayer_2.GetBestName] join your party.

One day while you are on the road an armored man comes riding towards you, moving slowly and openly in a manner that is clearly meant to indicate that he does not wish you any harm.\n\n"I am [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName]," he proclaims. "I have been told that you seek the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, and would stand by your side as you face this foe, my [Root.GetLordLady]!"
I accept your fealty!
I don't think so!

As you are breaking camp one day an armed woman approaches your encampment, moving with purpose but making certain that you and your companions can see her coming.\n\n"My [Root.GetLordLady], I have heard rumours that you plan to face Fredak, the Emperor of Embers," she tells you when she has come closer. "If you would let me accompany you, it would be an honor to fight by your side."
The honor would be mine!
I don't need you!

One evening while you and your companions are having a meal in a tavern an enormous man clad in ornate armor enters through the door. He spots your party and heads over to you.\n\n"I hear you seek the dragon," he says excitedly. "Allow me to join you, and I would fight by your side so that we might live with honor, or die with glory!" It almost sounds like the latter excites him more.
I like the way you think!
Go away!

As you leave the inn where you have been sleeping one morning you are approached by two people, one of them a very large old man and the other a young and fairly muscular woman who looks tiny in comparison.

"We would join your quest," the man says. "I would be your shield."

"And I would do my best to keep you all safe," the woman adds.
Two at once? Why not!
Your presence is unwanted!

A woman approaches you one day on the road, wearing light armor and carrying a bow that you suspect that she knows how to use. Judging by the look she gives some of your companions, she at least does not think highly of them.\n\n"I have heard that you are hunting a dragon," she says. "If you promise you will not be asking me to carry your burdens, I would gladly join you."
No carrying necessary!
I don't want you with me!

One of your guards begs a moment of your time one evening while you are about to retire for the night and brings over an incredibly large man.\n\n"I am [new_dragonslayer.GetName]," the big man says. "I have been waiting...," he pauses to count on his fingers "...three days for you to come here. I want to fight the dragon with you!"
I could use your strength!
Please go away!

A rider approaches you one day on the road, clad in armor bearing a noticeable amount of Christian iconography. The [new_dragonslayer.GetManWoman] brings [new_dragonslayer.GetHerHis] horse to a halt near yours and takes off [new_dragonslayer.GetHerHis] helmet before speaking.\n\n"I am [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName]," the [new_dragonslayer.GetManWoman] proclaims. "In Saint George's name, I would stand with you."
I welcome your aid!
I don't need a zealot!

As you are passing through a small market village a handsome man comes up to you, clearly happy to see you as he has a big smile on his face.\n\n"Ah, you have arrived!" he exclaims. "Allow me to introduce myself. I am [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName], and I wish to join you on your quest to the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers. That dreadful beast must be stopped."
Your company would be enjoyable!
I have no need of you!

In one village along the route you are travelling on your way to the lair of Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, you come across a dwarf, who introduces himself as [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName].\n\n"The dragon killed my kinsmen and stole our treasures," he tells you. "I would join you on your quest to avenge the former and recover the latter."
You will have your chance!
Get lost!

One day while you are having a meal by the roadside a handsome man armored in a suit of armor that is very decorated rides up to you. Judging by his posture, he thinks rather highly of himself.\n\n"I have heard you wish to slay a dragon," the man tells you, half-speaking and half-singing. "I wish to join you on your quest. Dragoslaying is what I do best!
You may accompany me!
I don't want your help!

One evening you are approached by a man introducing himself as [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName], who claims that he has heard about your quest.\n\n"Allow me to offer my services," he says. "I am better than the dragon. I have always been better than the dragon, and I will prove it to him, and to everyone." Something seems a tad suspect about the man, but you cannot tell what it is.
Your aid is welcome!
Leave my presence at once!

A man wearing fairly simple clothes and carrying a bow approaches your party one day and introduces himself as [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName], with the epithet being rather unusual for a peasant.\n\n"A little bird told me that you are hunting Fredak, the Emperor of Embers," he says. "I agree that the beast must be slain, and I would join you if you wuld have me. I know how to handle myself in a fight."
Peasant or no, you can come!
I don't associate with peasants!

As you are negotiating with an innkeeper regarding rooms for the night one of your companions lets slip that you are in the area because you are on a dragon hunt, which catches the woman's interest.\n\n"I have... an interest in dragon hunting, you know," she says. "The rooms are on the house. Moreover, if you would have me, I would gladly join you on your quest."
You look like you can use that sword!
There is no place for you in my party!

One day while you are having a meal at a tavern a kindly old man requests to share a cup of tea with you, and you accept his request. Introducing himself as [new_dragonslayer.GetBestName], he inquires about what brings you to the area, and you tell him about your quest.\n\n"I might know a thing or two about dragonslaying," he says. "Can I join you on your quest?
Your company would be welcome!
Go away, old man!

The population in [Root.GetName] has long had its share of seafarers, but of late many of them have seen fit to change their ways from mostly peaceful fishing to more aggressive raiding. Though they have yet to organize any raids worth speaking of, it is likely that it only is a matter of time before one or more of the captains decides to plague the coasts of the world.
That is not ideal...
As well they should!

The Wako population in [Root.GetName] has long been involved in small-scale raiding, but it has not been something that has been extensive enough that it has been more than a footnote. However, several influential pirate captains now consider the province their home, and they are actively recruiting sailors from the popular and spending their ill-gotten gains in port.
They'd better not raid my coasts...

The more influential pirate captains that once called [Root.GetName] their home have moved their operations elsewhere, and though there might still be a few pirates left in the province that is no more than what would be expected of any coastal province. Maybe this is only a temporary reprieve, or maybe the days of piracy are indeed drawing to a more permanent close.
Good riddance!
I have my own raiders...

The Wako pirates in [Root.GetName] grow bolder. One of the most influential captains, [wako_raider.GetBestName], has seen fit to assemble a large force of ships and raiders, and now seeks fame and fortune on the seas. Though [wako_raider.GetSheHe] has indicated that [wako_raider.GetSheHe] will be sailing abroad, it is hard to say whether [wako_raider.GetSheHe] will refrain from changing [wako_raider.GetHerHis] mind later.
Be gone!
Leave, and do not return!

Your band of Wako pirates has served you well for many years, but though your raids have been relatively successfuly the time has come for you to part ways. Hopefully the gold you have earned will be enough for anything you might wish to purchase. If not, maybe you will need to gather another crew and set forth on another series of raids.
It was fun while it lasted
